channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Apple just made your app obsolete? You've been 'Sherlocked.'
item.description: The controversial practice dates back to the 1990s when Apple introduced a service called Watson that critics say ripped off another company’s tool. Since then, small apps have said it has become a pattern.
item.content:encoded:
The controversial practice dates back to the 1990s when Apple introduced a service called Watson that critics say ripped off another company’s tool. Since then, small apps have said it has become a pattern.

(Image credit: NIC COURY/AFP via Getty Images)
item.dc:creator: Bobby Allyn

item.title: The economic and geopolitical reasons for China’s increased demand of gold
item.description: The price of gold soared in the first quarter of this year, driven in part by demand from China, where the economy is limping and other investment opportunities have underperformed.
item.content:encoded: The price of gold soared in the first quarter of this year, driven in part by demand from China, where the economy is limping and other investment opportunities have underperformed.
item.dc:creator: John Ruwitch

item.title: More than 1,000 athletes compete at the U.S. Olympic swimming trials in Indianapolis
item.description: The U.S. Olympic swimming trials are continuing in Indianapolis. More than 1,000 athletes are trying to make a 60-member squad. The stories of triumph and agony are equally compelling.
item.content:encoded: The U.S. Olympic swimming trials are continuing in Indianapolis. More than 1,000 athletes are trying to make a 60-member squad. The stories of triumph and agony are equally compelling.
item.dc:creator: Brian Mann

item.title: Critics say many of Apple's new iPhone features were copied from other popular apps
item.description: It’s been described as Apple’s “kiss of death.” When the tech giant reaches out to app developers, many fear that Apple is really looking to copy their product. At its annual developers’ conference this year, Apple was accused of just that.
item.content:encoded: It’s been described as Apple’s “kiss of death.” When the tech giant reaches out to app developers, many fear that Apple is really looking to copy their product. At its annual developers’ conference this year, Apple was accused of just that.
item.dc:creator: Bobby Allyn

item.title: The frogs are out after heavy rains in Florida
item.description: After a dry spell, heavy rains in Florida this week have finally brought out the frogs. We'll hear from them.
item.content:encoded: After a dry spell, heavy rains in Florida this week have finally brought out the frogs. We'll hear from them.
item.dc:creator: kerry sheridan

item.title: Researcher of ancient Mayan human remains uncovers site used in male, twin sacrifices
item.description: NPR's Sacha Pfeiffer talks with Rodrigo Barquera, a researcher at the Max-Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology in Germany, about a study revealing a surprise about ancient Mayan sacrifices.
item.content:encoded: NPR's Sacha Pfeiffer talks with Rodrigo Barquera, a researcher at the Max-Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology in Germany, about a study revealing a surprise about ancient Mayan sacrifices.
item.dc:creator: Jason Fuller

item.title: A ballot question could undermine efforts to remove 2 Arizona Supreme Court justices
item.description: Republican lawmakers in Arizona will ask voters whether state supreme court appointments should last for life. That would include two of the justices who voted to uphold an abortion ban from 1864.
item.content:encoded: Republican lawmakers in Arizona will ask voters whether state supreme court appointments should last for life. That would include two of the justices who voted to uphold an abortion ban from 1864.

item.title: U.S. surgeon general calls for tobacco-style warning labels for social media
item.description: NPR's Mary Louise Kelly speaks with U.S. Surgeon General Vivek Murthy about his call to put a warning label on social media platforms. Murthy believes social media can harm teenagers' mental health.
item.content:encoded: NPR's Mary Louise Kelly speaks with U.S. Surgeon General Vivek Murthy about his call to put a warning label on social media platforms. Murthy believes social media can harm teenagers' mental health.
item.dc:creator: Kathryn Fink

item.title: Israel to pause fighting from morning to evening along an aid corridor into Gaza
item.description: Israel has announced a daily pause in combat along an aid corridor in Gaza, to increase the amount of aid getting to civilians at a critical point in the Israel-Hamas war.
item.content:encoded: Israel has announced a daily pause in combat along an aid corridor in Gaza, to increase the amount of aid getting to civilians at a critical point in the Israel-Hamas war.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Estrin

item.title: We explained why woodpeckers hammer on metal — which struck a chord with listeners
item.description: Many NPR listeners responded to a story explaining why some woodpeckers hammer on metal, including a man who said it solved a 35-year mystery for him.
item.content:encoded: Many NPR listeners responded to a story explaining why some woodpeckers hammer on metal, including a man who said it solved a 35-year mystery for him.
item.dc:creator: Megan Lim
